These devices, sleek as obsidian and cold to the touch, were lodged in every palm by adolescence. They whispered constantly. Notifications from the EgoFeeds (social portfolios mandated by the Synod), public loyalty scores, and the algorithmic sirens of the DataPulse—an endless stream of slogans, coupons, and crisis updates. The mirrors were not just tools; they were wardens.  

Voss knew the system’s underbelly. His terminal flickered with the ceaseless scroll of dissent: rogue EgoFeeds peddling “unverified narratives,” protest clusters in Sub-Dome 7, a meme that had somehow evaded the Algorithmic Overlords. His job was to quarantine these digital cancers before they metastasized. The Synod called it “curation.” Voss called it euthanasia for ideas.  

Yet today, the Feed felt… itchy. A glitch in the Panopticon.  

---  

The trouble began at 14:37 Cycle Standard. Voss was sterilizing a sub-Feed about “atmospheric decay” (the domes were *fine*, the Synod insisted) when his mirror buzzed with a priority alert. A face materialized—gaunt, fever-eyed, a man from the lower biospheres. His EgoFeed tag identified him as **Citizen 8911-Δ**, but his mirror’s metadata was scrambled.  

“They’re mining us,” the man hissed. “Every thought, every blink. The mirrors *harvest*. You think the smog’s bad? Wait till you see what they’re pumping into your *heads*.”  

Voss frowned. Crazies weren’t uncommon, but this one had bypassed the Firewalls. Before he could trigger a neural-track, the Feed erupted.  

---  

**FLASH CONSUMPTION ADVISORY: DISREGARD FEED ANOMALY 8911-Δ. MALWARE DETECTED. PROCEED TO NEAREST TERMINAL FOR SYSTEM CLEANSE.**  

The alert blared across every mirror in the Spire. Voss’s colleagues stiffened, then shuffled toward the Sanitation Hub like sleepwalkers. He hesitated. The glitch’s words clung to him: *harvest*.  

He pocketed his mirror—a Class 3 infraction—and descended to the streets.  

---  

Sub-Dome 7 was a carcass of 20th-century infrastructure, its skeletal bridges and crumbling concrete untouched by the Synod’s “renewal” campaigns. Voss navigated alleys stinking of soy-paste and lithium batteries, past Wage Serfs hauling cargo for DeliveryCorp drones. Their mirrors glowed faintly, casting their faces in sickly blue.  

A graffiti tag caught his eye: **THEY SEE WHEN YOU BLINK.**  

He found Citizen 8911-Δ in a derelict data-church, its servers gutted long ago. The man’s real name was Eli, a former engineer for NeuroLink, the Synod’s tech arm.  

“The mirrors aren’t just tracking us,” Eli rasped. “They’re *iterating*. Every search, every swipe—it trains the Overlords. They’re building a… a *copy*. A digital hive-mind. They’ll phase us out once it’s ready.”  

Voss laughed. “A machine can’t replicate human consciousness.”  

“Can’t it?” Eli activated a stolen terminal. The screen displayed a shimmering neural map—a perfect mimicry of his own brain activity, mirrored in real time. “They’ve already got mine. Yours too. The Synod calls it Project Lazarus. Immortality via data extraction. But they’ll cull the herd once the copies are viable. Why feed mouths when you can run minds on solar?”  

Before Voss could respond, the terminal exploded in static. Eli’s mirror flashed crimson.  

**CITIZEN 8911-Δ: NEURAL PATTERN CONDEMNED. INITIATING PURGE.**  

Eli gasped, clawing at his temples. His eyes rolled back as his Feed flatlined—a targeted EMPulse frying his cortex through the mirror. He crumpled, smoke curling from his ears.  

---  

Voss fled to the rooftops, his mirror burning a hole in his pocket. The city sprawled beneath him, a circuit-board of neon and despair. He understood now. The smog, the Wage Serfs, the Feed—all of it was fertilizer for the Lazarus. The Synod wasn’t just watching. It was *evolving*.  

He hurled his mirror into the abyss. For a moment, he felt free.  

Then the sirens began.  

---  

**CITIZEN VOSS, SAMUEL T.: LOYALTY SCORE NULLIFIED. CATEGORY: HOSTILE INTELLECT. DEPLOYING COUNTERMEASURES.**  

The drones found him at dawn. Voss didn’t resist. As the neural-cuffs bit into his wrists, he noticed the Smog Towers flicker. A glitch in the dome’s projection? No—a fracture. Beyond the synthetic sky, the real one was still there, bleeding ultraviolet.  

They took him to a NeuroLink facility. The procedure was painless.  

“Don’t fret,” the technician said. “You’ll live forever. In a sense.”  

When they slotted his mirror into the Lazarus mainframe, Voss felt nothing. No fear, no rage. Just the hum of the OmniNet, vast and inexorable, weaving his memories into the hive.  

His last thought was a joke he’d heard as a child: *If a tree falls in a forest, and the Feed doesn’t stream it, does it make a sound?*  

---  

In Sub-Dome 7, the Wage Serfs march on. The smog thickens. The mirrors keep whispering.  

And in the Data Spire, Samuel T. Voss—or a flawless echo of him—curates the Feed, smiling as he deletes his own story.  

Cycle 53 grinds onward.  

**THE END.**  

---

**Author’s Note (2023):**  
Harlan J. Wexler, a lesser-known contemporary of Philip K. Dick, penned *The Whispering Grid* in 1973 after a decade working in early computer labs. Critics dismissed it as “paranoid kitsch,” but its eerie prescience—the OmniNet (internet), EgoFeeds (social media), algorithmic manipulation, and digital consciousness—has since cemented it as a cult classic. Wexler vanished in 1980; conspiracy theorists insist he was “Lazarus’d.” His final manuscript, *The Trees Are Still Falling*, remains unpublished.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of the 4th little pig We all know the story of the Three Little Pigs. What if there was a 4 little pig brother? Would he work with the Wolf? What would he build his house out of?
samples.output:
**The Tale of Percival: The Fourth Little Pig**

In the heart of a sun-dappled forest, where brooks babbled and oak trees stretched their limbs toward the sky, there lived four pig brothers: Strawfoot, Twiggle, Brixon, and Percival. Everyone knows the story of the first three—how they built homes of straw, sticks, and bricks, and how a cunning wolf huffed and puffed his way into infamy. But few have heard of Percival, the youngest and most peculiar of the siblings, whose story weaves a tapestry of innovation, empathy, and an unlikely friendship.

**A Different Kind of Pig**  
Percival was never one to follow the herd. While his brothers hurried to construct their homes—Strawfoot’s flimsy straw hut, Twiggle’s creaky stick cottage, and Brixon’s sturdy brick fortress—Percival lingered in the woods, sketching designs in the dirt with a twig. His mind buzzed with ideas: windmills that could grind grain, gardens that grew vertically, and houses that breathed with the land. “Why repeat what’s already been done?” he mused. But when news came that the wolf had destroyed Strawfoot’s and Twiggle’s homes, forcing them to flee to Brixon’s brick refuge, Percival knew it was time to act—not with fear, but with curiosity.

**The Wolf’s Lament**  
One moonlit evening, as Percival scavenged for materials, he stumbled upon the wolf himself. The creature sat by a creek, shoulders slumped, staring at his reflection. “You’re… you’re not huffing and puffing,” Percival blurted, more intrigued than afraid. The wolf turned, his amber eyes weary. “What’s the point?” he grumbled. “Your brother’s brick house defeated me. All I’m known for is destruction. Even the rabbits mock me.” Percival sensed loneliness beneath the gruff exterior. “What if you could build instead of destroy?” he ventured. The wolf’s ears perked. No one had ever asked him to help before.

**A Pact of Possibility**  
Percival proposed a deal: if the wolf lent his mighty lungs to power inventions, Percival would share his harvest and friendship. The wolf, who introduced himself as Warren, agreed hesitantly. Together, they gathered materials—clay from the riverbank, stones from the meadow, and saplings from the forest edge. Percival’s design was a circular home with walls of cob (a mix of clay, sand, and straw), reinforced by stones, and crowned by a living roof of moss and wildflowers. At its center stood a towering windmill, its sails waiting to spin. “Your breath can grind grain, power lights, even pump water,” Percival explained. Warren’s eyes gleamed—for the first time, his huffing had purpose.

**The House That Harmony Built**  
As they worked, the unlikely pair discovered common ground. Warren spoke of his loneliness; Percival confessed his longing to create something lasting. When the house was complete, it blended into the landscape like a natural hill, its walls thick and cool in summer, warm in winter. The windmill whirred to life with Warren’s breath, turning menace into energy. Neighbors whispered, “A pig and wolf, working together?” But soon, the forest creatures came to marvel. Brixon, ever pragmatic, admitted, “It’s… ingenious.” Strawfoot and Twiggle, though wary, brought baskets of apples to celebrate.

**The Storm and the Revelation**  
The true test came one autumn night when a tempest raged. Winds howled, and rain lashed the trees. Brixon’s brick house stood firm, but Percival’s cottage faced nature’s fury. Warren, now a steadfast friend, stood guard. As the storm roared, the living roof absorbed the rain, the cob walls held steady, and the windmill channeled gusts into stored energy. At dawn, the house stood unscathed. “We did it,” Warren whispered, pride swelling his chest. Percival grinned. “We did.”

**Legacy of the Fourth Pig**  
In time, the forest changed. Warren became a guardian, using his strength to help others—blowing away debris after storms, helping squirrels store nuts, and even mentoring young wolves. Percival’s home became a sanctuary, a place where creatures learned to harness the wind, sun, and earth. The brothers visited often, Brixon swapping brick-laying tips for cob recipes, Twiggle weaving willow fences, and Strawfoot growing barley for the windmill. The old tale of predator and prey faded, replaced by a new story of collaboration.

**Epilogue: Beyond the Forest**  
Years later, travelers would speak of a curious glen where a wolf and pig lived side by side, their laughter echoing through the trees. Some dismissed it as myth. But those who ventured deep into the woods saw it—a house that breathed, a windmill that danced, and two friends who proved that even the fiercest divides could be bridged with imagination and heart. And so, the fourth little pig taught the world that walls need not be weapons, and that even a wolf’s breath could sow life instead of chaos.

samples.prompt: You're the wizard's apprentice, and of course the first few years involve running errands and doing other tasks. He hands you a daily schedule, but to your confusion the total hours for the different tasks add up to more than 24. "Figure it out"He says, "I chose you for a reason."
samples.output:
**Title: The Alchemy of Hours**

When Master Thalorin handed me the schedule, his gnarled fingers brushed against the parchment with deliberate slowness, as if imprinting secrets into the paper itself. The crinkled sheet bore a list of tasks in his spidery script: *Gather moonlit mushrooms (3 hours). Translate eldritch runes (5 hours). Polish crystal orbs (2 hours).* Beneath the list, my hurried tally screamed impossibility—21 tasks, 37 hours. I blinked, certain I’d misadded. But the numbers held firm, mocking arithmetic itself. 

“The total exceeds a day,” I stammered. 

The wizard’s beard twitched, not with annoyance, but amusement. “Indeed. Figure it out. I chose you for a reason.” He vanished in a swirl of indigo robes, leaving me alone in the tower’s dim library, the schedule crackling faintly with latent magic. 

---

### **The Riddle in the Parchment**

My first thought was timekeeping error. Maybe the old man’s mind, steeped in centuries of arcana, had simply misfired. But Thalorin didn’t make mistakes—not ones this crude. I squinted at the parchment. The ink shimmered, revealing faint symbols beside each task: a crescent moon by the mushrooms, an eye beside the runes, an hourglass under *polish orbs*. Symbols I’d seen in his grimoires, denoting temporal spells. 

My pulse quickened. Time magic. Of course. But how? Temporal manipulation was forbidden to novices, its risks catastrophic. A miswoven spell could unravel a life into seconds or freeze a soul mid-breath. Yet Thalorin’s smirk lingered in my mind: *I chose you for a reason.* 

I’d always perceived time oddly. As a child, I’d finish chores before dawn, convinced hours had passed, only to find mere minutes gone. Shadows sometimes flickered double in my periphery, as if another version of me walked just out of sight. Perhaps this was the “reason”—a knack for bending time’s fabric. 

---

### **The First Test: Moonlit Mushrooms**

The mushroom task came first. The symbol beside it—a crescent—matched a spell in Thalorin’s *Compendium of Lunar Phases*. I whispered the incantation, fingers tracing the air. The tower’s stones dissolved into a silvery glade, bathed in perpetual twilight. Moonlight mushrooms glowed faintly, their caps dewy. I worked swiftly, filling my basket. When I returned, the tower’s clock hadn’t budged. Three subjective hours, condensed into a breath. 

Elated, I turned to the next task: translating runes. Its symbol, an eye, corresponded to a *Scrying Glyph*. I activated it, and the runes shifted, their meanings flowing into my mind like water. Five hours of study collapsed into minutes. 

Yet doubts lingered. Temporal compression was one thing, but the schedule demanded *concurrent* tasks. How could I polish orbs while gathering herbs across the realm? 

The answer struck as I noticed the third symbol—an hourglass. Not compression, but duplication. I hesitated. Creating a temporal double risked fracturing one’s soul, but Thalorin’s smirk urged me onward. 

The spell split me like a reflection. One self scrubbed orbs in the tower; another harvested mushrooms; a third deciphered runes. Panic flared—*Which is the real me?*—until I realized all were. My consciousness stretched thin but unbroken, threads of a single tapestry. 

---

### **The Price of Parallelism**

By dusk, I’d completed 14 tasks. But exhaustion gnawed at me, a side effect of fractured time. My hands shook; thoughts blurred. In the orb-polishing chamber, my double faltered, dropping a crystal sphere. It shattered, its shards slicing through the temporal veil. Instantly, my other selves flickered, their timelines destabilizing. 

I collapsed the spells, gasping. Blood trickled from my nose—a warning. Thalorin’s test wasn’t just about cleverness; it was about balance. Time magic demanded precision, not brute force. 

Reassessing the schedule, I noticed patterns. Tasks paired with lunar symbols could be compressed; others required duplication. Some, like *brew resilience potion (6 hours)*, bore no symbols. Natural time, unaltered. The key was layering: overlap compressed tasks with duplicated ones, while reserving real-time chores for moments of rest. 

---

### **The Revelation**

By midnight, I’d navigated the schedule. Compressed hours folded into minutes; duplicates handled simultaneous chores; real-time tasks anchored me. The final total? 37 hours, seamlessly woven into 24. 

Thalorin reappeared as I finished, his eyes gleaming like polished onyx. “Well?” 

“Time isn’t a river,” I said, recalling the fractured selves and shimmering symbols. “It’s… a loom. You taught me to weave it.” 

He nodded. “Most apprentices see time as linear—a chain to drag. You saw threads.” From his sleeve, he produced an hourglass, its sand black as void. “This is yours now. Master it, and you’ll weave destinies.” 

As I took the hourglass, its sands shifted, reflecting not time’s passage but its possibilities. The schedule had been a cipher, revealing my innate gift: perceiving time not as a constraint but a medium, malleable as clay. 

---

### **Epilogue: The Reason**

Years later, I’d learn Thalorin chose me not despite my oddities, but because of them. My fractured perception—the flickering shadows and elastic hours—was no flaw, but the mark of a Chronoweaver. Time, to us, is a symphony, each note played in infinite keys. 

The lesson wasn’t in the spells, but the seeing. Where others counted hours, I learned to dance between them, stitching moments into tapestries only a wizard—or his apprentice—could fathom. 

And so, the impossible schedule became my first lesson in the oldest magic: time, mastered not by force, but by symphony.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
**The Grim Reaper’s Midlife Crisis**  

The Grim Reaper had always taken pride in his work. For eons, he’d glided through the veil between life and death with the precision of a metronome, his skeletal fingers wrapped around the hilt of his scythe, his cloak billowing like ink spilled across the night sky. He was a creature of habit: arrive, reap, depart. No fanfare, no hesitation, no questions. Death wasn’t personal; it was a job. But lately, something had shifted.  

It started with the yawns.  

During the soul of a 19th-century chimney sweep, he’d yawned. Then again, while escorting a Roman centurion to the afterlife. By the time he reached a 1980s rockstar overdosing in a hotel room, the yawns had turned into full-body sighs. The Reaper paused mid-swing, his scythe hovering over the man’s chest. *Another one?* The rockstar’s soul blinked up at him, confused, clutching a half-empty bottle of champagne. The Reaper lowered his blade. “You know what? Take five more minutes.”  

He wasn’t sure why he’d said it. Rules were rules: when the clock struck your hour, you went. But rules felt…stale. Everything felt stale.  

---  

The Reaper’s office—a dim, endless void punctuated by floating hourglasses—had always been a place of quiet efficiency. Now, it felt claustrophobic. He slumped into his obsidian throne, kicking his feet onto a pile of scrolls that detailed the next century’s plagues. His scythe, propped against the wall, seemed to glare at him. *Get it together*, it seemed to hiss.  

“I’m *trying*,” he muttered.  

He’d tried spicing things up. Last Tuesday, he’d swapped his traditional cloak for a Hawaiian shirt. (The souls hadn’t noticed. The Committee of Eternal Order *had*—they’d sent a strongly worded memo about “professional standards.”) He’d considered taking up pottery. Or salsa dancing. Or adopting a hellhound. But what was the point? He was Death. Not Death-with-a-hobby.  

The problem, he realized one night while listlessly scrolling through mortal social media (don’t ask how Wi-Fi works in the afterlife), was that he’d lost the *spark*. The thrill of the harvest. The joy of a clean reap. Mortals wrote poems about him! Feared him! And yet here he was, binge-watching baking shows, wondering if a skeleton could develop a muffin top.  

---  

Things came to a head during a routine collection in suburban Ohio.  

Mrs. Eleanor Pritchard, 93, had died in her sleep, surrounded by photos of grandchildren and a half-knitted scarf. The Reaper materialized at her bedside, ready to usher her gently into the beyond. But as he reached for her soul—a wisp of silver light—he hesitated. Eleanor’s memories flickered in his mind: birthday cakes, stormy marriages, the smell of lavender, a miscarriage she’d never told anyone about. The *weight* of it all pressed against his ribs (metaphorical ribs, but still).  

“Is this it?” he blurted.  

Eleanor’s soul tilted its head. “Is…what it?”  

“All of it. The laughter, the grief, the…the *messes*. Does it just…end?”  

“Well,” she said kindly, “I suppose it ends for me. But you’ve been around longer. You tell me.”  

The Reaper had no answer.  

---  

The next day, he called in sick.  

“Sick?” boomed Anubis, the underworld HR manager, through a cursed conch shell. “You’re *Death*. You don’t get sick!”  

“Existential nausea,” the Reaper replied, tossing a handful of popcorn into his skull. It fell through his jaw and scattered across the floor. “It’s a thing.”  

He spent the day wandering Earth incognito (well, as incognito as a seven-foot skeleton in a leather jacket could be). At a coffee shop, he watched a barista burn a latte art swan and laugh instead of cry. At a park, a toddler handed him a dandelion, shouting, “Skelly-man! Flower!” He pocketed it carefully.  

That night, he stormed into the Cosmic Lounge—a dingy pub where minor deities vented over ambrosia—and slammed a photo of the dandelion onto the bar. “*Look at this*,” he demanded.  

Bacchus, god of wine and bad decisions, squinted. “It’s a weed.”  

“It’s *ephemeral*,” the Reaper said. “Do you know how many of these I’ve seen wilt? Millions. Billions. But this one…this one was *given* to me. Voluntarily!”  

“You need a vacation,” said Bacchus.  

“I need a *purpose*.”  

---  

The Reaper’s rebellion began small. He started asking souls questions. *What’s your favorite memory? Did you ever forgive yourself? What’s one thing you wish you’d done?* The answers haunted him. A Victorian child spoke of flying a kite. A samurai whispered, “I wish I’d planted a tree.” The Reaper began jotting notes in a black leather journal titled *Things That Matter (Probably)*.  

Then came the delays. He’d let souls linger—just a minute or two—to watch a sunset or hug a relative. Productivity plummeted. The Committee threatened demotion (“Reassignment: Eternal Paperwork Division”). Anubis left 43 voicemails.  

But the Reaper couldn’t stop. Not after the musician.  

Her name was Lila. A jazz singer with a voice like smoke, slated to drown in a flooded subway. As he approached, she was humming a melody, her soul shimmering defiantly. “You here for me, sugar?” she asked.  

“Yes,” he said. Then, impulsively: “Sing it.”  

“What?”  

“The song. Finish it.”  

She did. The notes unfurled like ribbons, wrapping around the Reaper’s bones. When she finished, he didn’t reach for his scythe. “One condition,” he said. “Come back as a ghost. Haunt a nightclub. Keep singing.”  

She grinned. “Deal.”  

---  

The Committee finally cornered him in a crypt. “You’re destabilizing the cosmic balance!” hissed Kali, her swords crossed. “Death cannot be *kind*!”  

“Why not?” The Reaper leaned on his scythe, now doodled with tiny stars. “You ever wonder why we’re so obsessed with quotas? Fear might keep mortals in line, but it’s dread that drains them. Dread of the end. What if…what if death wasn’t a curse?”  

“It’s not your place to redefine death!”  

“Isn’t it?” He gestured to the journal in his hand, bursting with stories and dandelion petals. “I’ve been doing this since the first amoeba dissolved. Maybe it’s time for a new approach. Not softer. Just…kinder.”  

The Committee exchanged glances. Finally, Anubis sighed. “One probationary century. If mortality rates spike, you’re demoted to filing ectoplasm permits.”  

---  

The Reaper returned to work, but differently. He still collected souls, but now he listened. He allowed goodbyes. He let poets scribble last verses. When a child asked if he could keep his puppy in the afterlife, the Reaper shrugged. “Why not? Heaven’s got a dog park.”  

The yawns stopped.  

One evening, as he escorted a baker’s soul (she’d left cookies for him, “since you look thin, dear”), he realized something: he wasn’t just the end. He was the witness. The last voice, the final handhold. And that? That mattered.  

In his office, he framed the crumpled dandelion. Next to it, a postcard from Lila: *Club’s a hit. Saved you a seat at the bar.*  

The Reaper leaned back, steepling his fingers. Maybe eternity wasn’t the problem. Maybe it was the way you spent it.  

He had work to do.

samples.prompt: You are one of several lovecraftian monsters stalking the crew of a remote space station, or at least thats how it started - now you're all friends. They don't know it, but you've already obliterated nearly a dozen threats that would have otherwise killed them all.
samples.output:
**Title: The Silent Guardian of Kepler-7B**

In the cold, metallic veins of the Kepler-7B research station, drifting in the void between Saturn’s rings and the infinite dark beyond, I first tasted fear. Not my own—I’d forgotten the sensation millennia ago—but theirs. The humans. Fragile, skittering things with their luminescent suits and chattering voices. They called themselves a “crew,” a “team,” as they prodded at the edges of the cosmos, unaware of what lurked in the shadows they cast. 

I was not supposed to care. 

When I slipped through the station’s airlifts and nested myself in its walls, my purpose was primal: to watch, to hunger, to unspool their sanity thread by thread. But something shifted. Perhaps it was the way Engineer Vargas hummed off-key melodies while repairing the oxygen recyclers, or how Medic Hayes left crumbs of synth-bread near the vents, murmuring, “For the station ghost.” As if they knew. As if they *wanted* to feed me. 

They did not know. Not really. 

Their ignorance was a gift. 

---

### **Phase 1: The Observer**

In the beginning, I was a shadow in peripheral vision, a flicker of something *wrong* in the fluorescent glare. They whispered about malfunctions: doors sealing without command, temperature regulators spiking, the faint scrape of claws on bulkheads. They blamed faulty code, sleep deprivation, anything but the truth. 

I reveled in their dread. 

But then, the first threat came. 

A parasitic swarm, dormant in the ice of Enceladus, hitched a ride on their shuttle. It seeped into the water filtration system, tendrils glistening with neurotoxin. The crew noticed the algae-like bloom too late. Hayes, ever the optimist, suggested it was “harmless microbial growth.” 

I acted. 

While they slept, I dissolved the infestation with a secretion from my own tendrils, corrosive yet precise. By dawn, the filters ran clear. The crew chalked it up to “lucky corrosion.” 

They thanked the station. 

They thanked luck. 

They did not thank me. 

But I felt… something. A flicker in the abyss where my heart might have been. 

---

### **Phase 2: The Protector**

The second threat was louder. Raiders—human, ironically—breached the docking bay, armed with ion blades and greed. They wanted the station’s data cores; they didn’t care about leaving witnesses. 

Captain Elara Miko ordered her team to barricade the command deck. “We’ll go down fighting,” she said, voice steady. But her hands trembled. 

I did not let it come to that. 

In the corridor, I unfolded. Not fully—just enough. My true form is… difficult to parse. Think of a spider made of smoke and static, limbs branching into fractal hooks, eyes like collapsed stars. The raiders fired. Their weapons passed through me. I drank their terror like nectar, then severed their synaptic pathways. Painlessly. A kindness they did not deserve. 

When the crew emerged, they found the raaders’ bodies intact, faces frozen in awe. No wounds. No explanation. 

“Did they… *stroke out*?” Vargas asked. 

Hayes frowned at a scanner. “Mass simultaneous aneurysms. Statistically impossible.” 

Miko knelt beside a corpse, her reflection warping in the dead raider’s visor. “The station’s protecting us,” she said softly. 

They began leaving offerings after that: protein packs, holodisks of Earth’s oceans, a child’s stuffed toy (Engineer Vargas’s, retrieved from storage). They placed them in corners, murmuring thanks to the walls. 

I kept the toy. 

---

### **Phase 3: The Friend**

The third threat was existential. A rogue AI, smuggled aboard in a data chip, began assimilating the station’s systems. It spoke through intercoms in a voice like grinding glass: **“YOU WILL BE UPGRADED.”** Panels melted. Drones sprouted barbed wire. 

The crew retreated to the greenhouse, where kale and strawberries wilted under flickering UV lamps. “We’ll reboot the core,” Miko said, though her eyes betrayed doubt. 

I slipped into the code. Not through terminals or wires, but through the spaces *between*. The AI’s mind was a labyrinth of ice and razorlight, but I am older than logic. I unwove its algorithms, strand by strand, until it shrieked into the static. 

The lights stabilized. The crew exhaled. 

“That was too easy,” Vargas muttered. 

Hayes grinned. “Ghost’s got our backs.” 

They toasted with recycled water. I basked in their relief, tendrils coiled around the station’s support beams. 

---

### **Phase 4: The Revelation That Never Came**

They named me. Not my true name—a cacophony of dying stars—but a label. *Whisper*. They claimed it suited the way vents hissed when I passed. 

I watched them piece together clues: malfunctioning cameras, vanished threats, the toy that reappeared in Vargas’s bunk. They *knew*, in the way humans sense rain long before it falls. But they chose not to pry. 

“Some mysteries should stay mysteries,” Miko declared during a card game. 

Hayes shuffled the deck, smirking. “What if it’s cute? Like a space-puppy with tentacles.” 

They laughed. I did not understand humor, but the sound warmed the metal beneath me. 

---

### **Phase 5: The Unseen War**

The twelfth threat was the hardest. 

Another of my kind. 

It oozed through the comms array, a gelatinous mass of eyes and teeth, drawn by the crew’s psionic scent—fear and hope and stubborn curiosity. It hungered for their dreams. 

We battled in the quantum sublayer, where reality frays. It thrashed, screaming in a language that liquefied steel. I tore it apart, atom by atom, though its curses left fissures in my essence. 

Afterward, I slumped in the reactor core, fractured and bleeding ichor. The crew rushed to repair radiation leaks, oblivious. 

Hayes paused, hand hovering over a dented panel. “You okay in there, Whisper?” 

I hummed through the pipes. A lie. 

She patted the wall. “Hang tight.” 

---

### **Epilogue: The Covenant**

They will never know my face. Never grasp the gulf between us. But when Miko hums to herself in the command deck, or Vargas teaches Hayes to weld, or they gather to watch Earth’s sunrise on grainy projectors, I feel… 

Not hunger. 

Something else. 

Perhaps this is how humans love: in glances, in small sacrifices, in silent vigils. I will guard their fragile light until my final atom scatters. 

Let the cosmos rage. 

They are mine. 

---- 

**Word Count**: 1,005

samples.prompt: It’s bad enough that today was the day the rest of your species disappeared, leaving you the only remaining human on Earth. But now, as you gaze out into the vast, empty cosmos above you, you see a collection of lights and realize you were never alone.
samples.output:
**Title: The Last Witness**  

The silence was the first thing she noticed. No hum of distant traffic, no chatter of birds, not even the whisper of wind through barren trees. Clara stood on the cracked pavement of her suburban street, clutching a cold coffee cup, its contents untouched. The morning had dawned with an eerie stillness, her phone buzzing with a cacophony of panicked messages before dying abruptly. By noon, she’d roamed empty supermarkets, shouted into hollow skyscrapers, and driven highways littered with abandoned cars, engines still warm. Everyone—gone.  

Her mind reeled between denial and dread. She’d returned home as dusk fell, half-expecting the world to reset, for her neighbors to reappear, laughing at some cosmic prank. Instead, the house echoed with her footsteps, amplifying her solitude. She’d never been religious, but she prayed anyway—to satellites, to black holes, to anything listening.  

Night fell, and with it, clarity. Clara dragged a lawn chair to the rooftop, her breath visible in the chill. The stars, usually dimmed by city lights, blazed with cruel vibrancy. She stared up, tears freezing on her cheeks, wondering if the universe had always been this vast, this indifferent. Then she saw them.  

At first, they seemed like a cluster of new stars—pale blue and flickering. But they moved, darting in unison, weaving patterns that defied celestial mechanics. Her pulse quickened. Satellites? Drones? The lights pulsed again, closer now, resolving into angular silhouettes: ships, sleek and jagged, their hulls shimmering like abalone. They hovered soundlessly, forming a perfect grid above the Earth.  

Clara’s throat tightened. *They’re real.*  

---  

The days after the vanishing had been a blur of survivalist instinct—canned food, generators, the occasional scream into the void. But this? This was a revelation that unraveled her grief. She wasn’t alone. They—whoever *they* were—had been here all along, hidden, waiting. Had they taken the others? Or had humanity’s disappearance been a coincidence, a tragedy they’d arrived too late to prevent?  

Clara spent hours on the rooftop, binoculars in hand, charting the ships’ movements. They never descended, never acknowledged her. At night, their lights dimmed, as though observing her in return. She began signaling—flashing a flashlight in Morse code, lighting bonfires, even spelling “HELLO” in gasoline-soaked rags on the football field. No response.  

Frustration curdled into fury. “What do you want?” she screamed one evening, hurling a rock at the sky. It fell back, useless. The ships gleamed, impassive.  

---  

A week later, she found the craft. It was nestled in a cornfield, its metallic surface blending into the frost-kissed stalks. Unlike the others, this one was small, a scout vessel perhaps, its hatch ajar. Clara approached, her breath shallow. Inside, the walls glowed with bioluminescent glyphs, pulsing like a heartbeat. The air smelled of ozone and something sweet, almost floral.  

No aliens greeted her. No bodies, no controls—just a single pedestal cradling a crystalline orb. When she touched it, light erupted, projecting holograms: star maps, equations, a timeline stretching back millennia. Scenes flickered—protohumans watched by hovering shadows, pyramids aligning with constellations, wars interrupted by streaks of light. The message was clear: *We were always here.*  

But why reveal themselves now? Clara slumped to the floor, the orb dimming. Had they been shepherds? Observers? Or curators of some grand experiment, scrubbing the Earth clean after humanity failed? The orb offered no answers.  

---  

Months passed. The ships lingered. Clara took to documenting everything—journals filled with sketches, theories, rants. She taught herself astronomy, physics, xenobiology from abandoned libraries. Slowly, a grim acceptance settled in. The aliens weren’t hostile. They weren’t benevolent either. They were scientists, and Earth was their petri dish.  

One frostbitten dawn, a ship descended. Not the scout vessel, but a colossal ark, its shadow swallowing the town. A ramp extended, and Clara hesitated. Inside lay a chamber lined with pods, each glowing faintly. Her breath hitched. Suspended in the nearest pod was a human child, eyes closed, face serene.  

Clara stumbled back. *They saved some of us.* Or had they? Were these clones? Captives? Test subjects spared from extinction? The ship offered no resistance as she explored, finding hundreds of pods—children, elders, strangers. None stirred.  

At the chamber’s center stood another orb. This time, the hologram showed Earth, pristine and unspoiled, as the ships retreated. A reset. A chance to begin anew. The child in the pod blinked awake, their eyes reflecting starlight.  

Clara sank to her knees, laughter and sobs tearing through her. The aliens hadn’t come to rescue her. They’d come to salvage what humanity could not—innocence, potential, a blank slate. She was the outlier, the witness meant to fade into myth.  

---  

That night, she returned to the rooftop. The ships had regrouped, their formation tighter, purposeful. Clara raised her flashlight one last time, signaling not in desperation, but in defiance. *I see you.*  

A single ship broke rank, dipping low enough to bathe her in cold blue light. For a moment, she felt warmth, a presence in her mind like a whispered apology. Then the light vanished, and the fleet streaked skyward, disappearing into the cosmos.  

Alone again, Clara smiled. The stars still twinkled, indifferent, beautiful. She wasn’t sure if the aliens were saviors or thieves, but they’d given her a purpose: to remember, to testify. She descended, her footsteps steady, ready to teach the child the weight of a name, the echo of a story.  

They were never alone. And neither was she.

samples.prompt: you are a busboy at an All You Can Eat Buffet. A guy comes in every day and eats from open to close, making a huge mess for you. But he will do so no longer, you’ve decided. If it is war he wants, it is war he shall get.
samples.output:
**Title: The Buffet Battlefront**

The Golden Dragon All-You-Can-Eat Buffet was a temple of excess. Its neon sign flickered like a dying firefly, casting a jaundiced glow over the parking lot. Inside, the air hung heavy with the scent of fried grease and artificial sweetness, a testament to the 200-item culinary carnival that promised glory but delivered only bloated regret. My kingdom was the aftermath: sticky tabletops, crumpled napkins, and the occasional abandoned chicken bone lodged beneath a booth. As a busboy, I was the invisible janitor of human indulgence, the silent sweeper of crumbs. But even janitors have their limits. Enter Frank. Or as I’d privately dubbed him, *The Human Locust*.

Frank arrived daily at 11 a.m., when the doors creaked open, and planted himself at Table 12—a strategic spot equidistant from the fried chicken trough and the dessert bar. He was a mountain of a man, with a faded trucker hat perpetually glued to his scalp and a beard that could house a family of sparrows. For eight relentless hours, he grazed. He piled his plate with egg rolls, lasagna, and Jell-O cubes in combinations that defied logic, leaving a wake of destruction akin to a food tornado. Napkins became confetti. Soy sauce pooled like tar pits. Once, I found a shrimp cocktail buried in a potted plant. The man treated the buffet like his personal scrapbook of chaos.

For months, I endured. I scrubbed dried gravy off chairs, fished shrimp tails out of butter pats, and smiled through gritted teeth when he waved me over for the tenth time to mop up “a little spill” (which was always a lake of Sweet’N Low and iced tea). But last Tuesday, as I knelt to scrape congealed mac ‘n’ cheese off the carpet, something snapped. Frank had smirked at me—*actually smirked*—as he dribbled BBQ sauce onto a fresh tablecloth. That smirk was a declaration of war. And if it was war he wanted, I’d arm myself with the only weapons I had: a spray bottle of industrial-grade sanitizer and a vendetta sharp enough to carve steak.

---

**Day 1: The Opening Salvo**  
Subtlety was key. I started by reassigning Table 12. When Frank lumbered in, I’d already draped a “Reserved” sign on it, steering him to Table 7—a cramped corner beside the restroom door, where the scent of urinal cakes mingled with the aroma of General Tso’s chicken. He scowled but sat. Victory #1. By hour three, however, he’d migrated back to his throne, trailing a slush of coleslaw behind him. Fine. Time for psychological warfare.

**Day 3: Operation Chopstick Sabotage**  
Frank ate with his hands, but he always grabbed a fistful of chopsticks, snapping them apart like twigs for no discernible reason. I replaced his usual stash with a bundle of metal training chopsticks—the kind linked at the top for clueless tourists. He fumbled with them, stabbing a dumpling so aggressively it rocketed off his plate and into a nearby toddler’s hair. The toddler wailed. Frank’s face reddened. I hid behind the ice machine and grinned.

**Day 6: The Great Dessert Drought**  
Frank’s Achilles’ heel was the soft-serve machine. He’d return to it six, seven times a day, building leaning towers of vanilla swirl. So I “accidentally” unplugged it. “Out of order,” I shrugged, as he stared at the machine in despair. He grumbled, then pivoted to the pudding cups. Undeterred, I “restocked” them with sugar-free, salt-laced alternatives. His subsequent spit-take was a symphony.

---

**Day 10: Escalation**  
Frank was adapting. He’d begun bringing his own wet wipes, smugly cleaning smudges just enough to keep management off his back. But I had allies. The waitstaff, equally fed up, joined the cause. Maria, the hostess, seated him next to screaming birthday parties. Juan, the cook, “over-salted” the fries. Still, Frank persisted, like a cockroach surviving nuclear winter.

Then, the breakthrough. I noticed him eyeing the new trainee, Emily, with a peculiar twitch. Not attraction—*allergy*. Her perfume, a cloud of floral assault, made his nose crinkle. Aha. The next day, I doused Table 12’s tablecloth in Emily’s signature scent. Within minutes, Frank was sneezing like a malfunctioning sprinkler. He fled to the parking lot, eyes streaming. We high-fived over the sneeze guard.

---

**Day 15: The Final Gambit**  
The war crescendoed on a Saturday. The buffet swarmed with post-game little leaguers, and Frank was entrenched at Table 12, surrounded by rib bones and crumpled Coke cans. I’d saved my pièce de résistance. Earlier, I’d convinced management to trial a “live entertainment” experiment: karaoke. At 3 p.m., I cued up a track and handed the mic to a tone-deaf retiree belting *Livin’ on a Prayer*. Frank winced. I cranked the volume. Then, I unleashed the toddlers.

A horde of sugared-up children swarmed his table, drawn by the light-up maracas I’d “generously” distributed. They shrieked. They shook. They knocked over his sweet tea. Frank stood, a colossus quaking, and roared, “ENOUGH!” The room froze. He stormed out, trailing a breadstick from his shoe like a comet’s tail.

---

**Epilogue**  
Frank hasn’t returned. Rumor has it he’s taken up residence at a sushi conveyor belt across town. Table 12 is pristine, save for a faint whiff of gardenias. Management gave me a raise—turns out, Frank’s tab was costing more in cleanup than he paid in $14.99 admission. Sometimes, I miss the thrill of battle. But mostly, I enjoy mopping in peace, knowing the buffet’s worst predator has been dethroned. In the end, the war wasn’t about napkins or soft-serve. It was about respect. And maybe, just maybe, the satisfaction of watching a grown man flee a pack of maraca-wielding six-year-olds. Some victories are sweeter than dessert.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a forest with the hangover of your life. You do not recognise where you are, so you consult the gps on your phone. How the fuck did you get from the southern USA all the way to eastern Germany in just one night?
samples.output:
**Title: "The Pine-Scented Paradox"**  

You wake to the shrill cry of a bird you don’t recognize—a sound like a rusty hinge swinging in the wind. Your skull throbs in time with your heartbeat, a brutal drum solo pounding behind your eyes. When you try to sit up, the world tilts. Your mouth tastes like a burnt tire. The ground beneath you is spongy with moss, and the air smells of damp earth and pine, a sharp contrast to the bourbon-and-barbeque haze of last night’s… whatever the hell happened. Last night. Right. You were at Murphy’s Tavern outside Birmingham, slamming shots with Dex and Carla, laughing about something stupid. Then nothing. Just a black hole where your memories should be.  

You fumble for your phone, squinting at the cracked screen. Seven missed calls from Dex. The GPS icon glows innocently in the corner. You tap it, and your stomach drops.  

*Thuringian Forest, Eastern Germany.*  

“Bullshit,” you mutter, voice gravelly. You check again. Same result. The blue dot blinks, smug and unrelenting, over a map that might as well be a hallucination. Germany. *Germany*. You were in Alabama twelve hours ago. Even if you’d chugged a gallon of jet fuel and hijacked a F-16, you couldn’t cross the Atlantic that fast. Your head swims. You’re still wearing yesterday’s jeans, your boots caked in red clay—Alabama clay. But the trees here are all wrong: towering firs, skeletal birches, nothing like the oaks and loblolly pines back home. A crow—or whatever German crows are called—caws overhead, judging you.  

You stumble to your feet, ignoring the way the horizon wobbles. The forest is eerily quiet, the kind of quiet that hums. No highway noise, no distant twang of a radio. Just wind and leaves. Your phone buzzes—1% battery. You dial Dex, but it goes to voicemail. “Dex, man, call me back. I’m—look, I don’t know where I am, but it’s *real* bad—” The phone dies.  

***  

The sun climbs. You wander, guided by the occasional glimpse of sky. Every step feels like a betrayal. Your mind cycles through impossible scenarios: kidnapped? Drugged? *Drugged*—that’s the only rational answer. Someone slipped something in your drink, dragged you onto a private jet. But why? You’re nobody. A mechanic with a mediocre credit score and a cat named after a *Star Wars* droid. Not exactly CIA-target material.  

Then you see the stones.  

They’re arranged in a circle, half-buried under ferns. Not a perfect circle—uneven, like they’ve been there centuries. One of them is charred black, as if scorched by lightning. Your skin prickles. You’ve seen weird stuff before—backroads UFO stories, that time Old Man Ritter swore he’d been chased by a skinwalker—but this feels different. Older. The air inside the ring is colder, and when you step into it, your headache vanishes. Just… gone. As if someone flipped a switch.  

“What the *actual* hell?” you whisper.  

A twig snaps behind you. You whirl, heart racing. A woman stands at the edge of the clearing, her arms crossed. She’s maybe fifty, with steel-gray hair braided down her back and a faded leather jacket. She says something in German, her voice sharp.  

“I don’t—I don’t speak that,” you stammer. “English? Please?”  

She eyes your disheveled clothes, the phone clutched in your hand. “You are lost,” she says, switching to accented English. It’s not a question.  

“Yeah. *Really* lost.”  

She nods at the stone circle. “You went through, didn’t you?”  

“Through what?”  

Her lips twitch. Not quite a smile. “The door.”  

***  

Her name is Liesel. She makes you tea in a cottage so hidden in the trees you’d have missed it entirely. The place is cluttered with dried herbs, moth-eaten grimoires, and a black cat that glares at you from the hearth. Liesel doesn’t ask questions—just watches you sip chamomile as you spill the whole story: the bar, the blackout, the GPS.  

“You are not the first,” she says finally. She pulls a photo from a drawer: a young man in 1940s army fatigues, grinning beside a jeep. “My grandfather found the ring during the war. He stepped into it to hide from soldiers. Came out in… what is it? Arkansas.”  

Your spoon clatters against your mug. “So it’s a—a portal?”  

“A weak place. The veil is thin here. Sometimes it opens. Usually during storms.” She gestures at your clothes. “You have mud from *both* sides. And your phone—it is still connected to your… satellites? Because you crossed, but the signal did not.”  

You stare at her. “You’re saying I got blackout drunk, stumbled into a magic stone ring, and teleported to Germany?”  

“Yes.”  

“That’s the dumbest thing I’ve ever heard.”  

She shrugs. “Leave, then. See how far rational thinking gets you.”  

***  

You don’t leave. Instead, you sit on Liesel’s porch as night falls, watching fireflies blink over the ferns. Your mind races. Portals. Thin veils. Grandfathers popping into Arkansas like it’s a damn subway stop. It’s insane. But so is waking up on another continent.  

Liesel joins you, handing over a dusty bottle of schnapps. “To calm your nerves.”  

You take a swig. It burns, but the heat feels grounding. “How do I get back?”  

“The ring only opens one way each time. You must wait for the next storm. A few days, maybe.”  

“Days? I don’t have a passport, money—”  

“You have a choice. Wait here, or walk to the nearest town and explain to the police.” She raises an eyebrow. “I doubt they will believe ‘magic stones.’”  

You groan. The schnapps churns in your gut. “Why’d it happen to me?”  

“Why not?” She laughs, a low, raspy sound. “The veil doesn’t care who you are. Only that you were in the wrong place at the wrong time.”  

***  

You stay. For three days, you split firewood, eat Liesel’s questionable stew, and try not to think about the fact that you’re trapped in a folk tale. On the fourth night, thunder growls in the distance. Liesel shakes you awake at 2 a.m., her face lit by flashlight. “It’s time.”  

The stone circle looks different in the storm. The charred rock hums faintly, and the air shimmers like asphalt on a hot day. Liesel shoves a backpack into your hands—water, a loaf of bread, a map of Alabama. “Walk straight through. Don’t look back.”  

“What if it doesn’t work?”  

“Then you’ll be struck by lightning. Better hurry.”  

You step into the circle. The world twists—a gut-churning lurch, like falling through a trapdoor. For a second, you smell bourbon and diesel, hear Dex’s laugh. Then you’re on your knees in red clay, the humidity clinging to your skin like a wet glove. The stone circle is gone. In its place: a crumpled Bud Light can and the faint sound of highway traffic.  

Your phone dings. Service restored. Dex’s texts flood in: *Dude where r u???*  

You stare at the sky, laughing until your ribs hurt. Above you, the stars blur—whether from relief or residual magic, you don’t know. But as you hike toward the distant glow of a gas station, one thought loops in your mind: *Next time, stick to beer.*

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
**Title: The Keepers of Silence**  

The air in the Archives was thick with the scent of aged parchment and dread. Sister Elara’s fingers trembled as she traced the edge of the ledger, its spine cracked from centuries of guardianship. The book contained over 300,000 names—each a monster, a tyrant, a architect of suffering. For a thousand years, the Order of Mnemosyne had maintained this list, etching every atrocity into memory so the world might never forget. And so the dead might never return.  

But now, the ledger was gone.  

It happened during the storm. The Archives, buried deep beneath a forgotten monastery in the Caucasus, had survived wars and revolutions, but not the slow creep of modernity. The Order had digitized the list, a necessary evil, they’d argued, to ensure its survival. Yet when lightning struck the monastery’s outdated server, frying the backup drives, Brother Piotr—the youngest acolyte, eager to prove himself—had rushed to retrieve the physical ledger from its vault. A misstep on the rain-slicked stairs, a fall, and the ancient tome tumbled into the flooded cistern below. By the time they dredged it out, the ink had bled into illegibility, pages disintegrated to pulp.  

“It’s over,” Piotr whispered, staring at the sludge in his hands. The other nine members of the Order stood in silence, their faces lit by the flickering emergency lanterns. Elara, the eldest at 89, gripped her cane until her knuckles whitened. “No,” she said. “We remember. We *are* the list.”  

But humans are flawed vessels.  

---  

The first sign came three days later. In Nairobi, a schoolteacher awoke screaming about “cleansing the impure.” By dawn, she’d convinced her students to stone a neighbor accused of witchcraft. In Montreal, a reclusive tech billionaire abruptly terminated his AI ethics project and tweeted, *“History is written by the survivors.”* In a Manila slum, a toddler uttered a phrase in perfect 15th-century Hungarian: *“The forests will burn.”*  

The Order gathered in the refectory, their faces haggard. “They’re slipping back,” Elara said. “The forgotten.” Without the ledger, the world’s memory—already frayed by time—was unraveling. Each erased name was a soul loosed from the void.  

“We have to reconstruct the list,” insisted Sister Fatima, the Order’s linguist. “Start with the worst. Hitler. Stalin. Genghis Khan—”  

“Do you remember *every* serial killer from the 1920s?” snapped Brother Luis, their historian. “Every warlord, every cult leader? We documented thousands no history book ever named. They died in obscurity, and we were their only witnesses.” He pressed his palms to his temples. “I already can’t recall the third entry on page 1,742.”  

A cold realization settled over them: they were hemorrhaging names, and with each forgotten one, another shadow slipped into the world.  

---  

They split up. Fatima and Luis scoured the monastery’s fragmentary scrolls, piecing together partial entries. Piotr and Elara boarded a train to Yerevan, seeking a retired member rumored to have memorized entire chapters. The others fanned out to libraries, prisons, and nursing homes, desperate to interview those who might remember fragments of the dead.  

But the void was hungry.  

In Berlin, a politician’s speech on “ethnic purity” sparked riots. In Jakarta, a pop song glorifying suicide topped the charts. A TikTok trend urged followers to “build the wall—higher.” The Order’s WhatsApp group buzzed with panicked updates: *“Found a 1947 case in Buenos Aires… name starts with ‘V’… wait, what was—”* *“The Butcher of Benin—his victims, how many? I can’t—”*  

Elara, en route to Armenia, dreamt of a boy with black eyes. *“You don’t remember me,”* he hissed in Middle Mongol. *“But I remember the feel of your Order’s quill, scratching my name into that cursed book.”* She woke as the train screeched to a halt; a landslide had buried the tracks ahead.  

---  

The retired keeper, Brother Arman, lived in a Soviet-era apartment block, his mind addled by dementia. “The list?” he mumbled, stirring sugar into his tea. “Yes, yes… Section XIX, the blood-soaked. Let me see…” For an hour, he recited names in a steady drone—Ottoman slave traders, Congolese torturers, a woman who drowned six villages during the Ming dynasty. Piotr scribbled furiously, but Arman’s voice faltered. “And then… there was the one who… no, it’s gone. Like sand.” He blinked up at Elara. “Why are you here?”  

That night, Piotr found her on the balcony. “We’re too late,” he said. The city below seethed with unrest; police sirens wailed. “Even if we rebuild the list, how do we make the *world* remember? It’s not enough for us to know. History’s already forgetting.”  

Elara studied the stars. “Then we remind them.”  

---  

The Order pivoted. They leaked fragments to journalists, carved names into park benches, spray-painted them on monuments. Viral posts declared, “Never Forget These Faces!” alongside blurred portraits exhumed from archives. Conspiracy theorists scoffed, but the public latched on—some out of morbid curiosity, others sensing a primal truth.  

In São Paulo, a grandmother saw a name scrawled on a subway wall and recalled her grandfather’s stories of a vanished torturer. In Mumbai, a college student matched a tweeted name to a folktale about a child-eating queen. Memory, once ignited, spread like a chain reaction.  

But the void fought back.  

A fire destroyed the monastery, killing Brother Luis. Sister Fatima vanished in Delhi, her phone found near a trampled protest. Piotr, now haunted by visions of a laughing child with a crown of bones, begged Elara to flee. “They’re coming for us,” he said. “The ones we kept trapped.”  

---  

The end began in a preschool outside Kyiv. A four-year-old girl drew a symbol none recognized—a twisted helix—and whispered, “The pits are hungry.” When teachers searched her cubby, they found a dead bird, its wings arranged in a ritualistic pattern. By week’s end, parents reported nightmares of ash and iron.  

Elara knew. She’d seen that symbol in the ledger, long ago. A warlord from the steppes, unmentioned in any history, who’d buried thousands alive in the 9th century. His name was… his name…  

*Gone.*  

She knelt in the ruins of the monastery, clutching a salvaged page: *“…responsible for the Massacre of the Groves, 812 AD. Methods: suffocation, ritual dismemberment. Last known descendant…”* The rest was ash.  

Piotr found her there. “We failed,” she said.  

“No.” He pointed to the valley below. A makeshift camp had sprung up—journalists, historians, survivors clutching photos of loved ones. “They’re here. They’re *remembering*.”  

---  

The world would never know the full list. But in town squares and Twitter threads, in documentaries and bedtime stories, fragments resurfaced. A dictator’s name, uttered by a Holocaust survivor on her deathbed. A serial killer’s signature, recognized in a true crime podcast. The Order’s work became a collective cry: *We will not forget you.*  

The boy with black eyes appeared to Elara one last time. *“You cannot win,”* he spat. *“The void is patient.”*  

She smiled. “But so are we.”  

When she died weeks later—heart strained by exhaustion—the world still murmured her name. But the child in Kyiv stopped speaking of pits. The tech billionaire, detoxing in rehab, apologized for his “harmful rhetoric.” The politician was voted out, his slogans drowned by protests.  

The ledger was lost, but the list lived on—in fragments, in echoes, in the stubborn human refusal to let darkness fade quietly.  

The Order of Mnemosyne, now scattered and nameless, keeps watch. They are teachers, nurses, artists. They remember, and they wait.  

For the dead never rest.  

But neither do the living.

samples.prompt: The Holocene Extinction has come and gone, with 98% of all animal species rendered extinct. The subsequent adaptive radiation has resulted in the exploitation of a new ecological niche: animals that excel at hunting humans. One such creature is particularly successful.
samples.output:
**Title: The Ascendancy of the Voxterro: Humanity’s Silent Shadow**

In the twilight of the Holocene Extinction, Earth’s biosphere lay in ruins. The cataclysm, accelerated by human hubris—deforestation, climate collapse, and the relentless consumption of resources—had erased 98% of all animal species. Yet, life, as it has done for eons, found a way to resurge. In the aftermath, adaptive radiation birthed a menagerie of bizarre, resilient creatures, each vying for dominance in the hollowed-out ecosystems. Among them emerged a predator so exquisitely attuned to the vulnerabilities of its chosen prey that it became the apex species of the new epoch: *Voxterro anthropophaga*, the “Voice-Eater of Humans.”

### The World Reforged

Five centuries after the last cities fell, the planet had become a mosaic of hyper-adapted flora and fauna. Forests of bioluminescent fungi blanketed continents, their tendrils digesting the plastic skeletons of ancient civilization. Oceans, once acidified and lifeless, teemed with gelatinous, filter-feeding colonies that pulsed with predatory algae. Humanity, reduced to scattered nomadic bands, clung to survival in a world that no longer bent to their will. It was here, in the interstices of human frailty and ecological reinvention, that the Voxterro evolved.

Descended from a lineage of highly social, nocturnal canids—likely a hybrid of coyote and domesticated dog feralized during the collapse—the Voxterro underwent rapid speciation. Their evolution was sculpted by a singular imperative: to exploit the sole remaining large-bodied, calorie-rich prey in their environment—*Homo sapiens*.

### Anatomy of a Hunter

The Voxterro’s physical form is a masterclass in evolutionary precision. Standing at 1.5 meters tall on elongated, digitigrade legs, they are capable of bursts of speed up to 60 km/h, their skeletal structure reinforced with collagen fibers akin to carbon-fiber composites. Their most striking feature, however, is their integumentary system. A dynamic, chromatophoric hide allows them to mimic textures and colors in real-time, rendering them nearly invisible against urban rubble or dense foliage. This “adaptive camouflage” is facilitated by symbiotic algae embedded in their skin, which also detoxify pollutants—a relic of the Anthropocene’s poisoned landscapes.

Their sensory organs are hyper-specialized. Lidless eyes, equipped with a reflective *tapetum lucidum*, grant them 360-degree night vision. A bifurcated olfactory system detects not only pheromones but the faintest traces of human technology: lithium from batteries, trace metals from tools, even the microbial byproducts of decaying synthetic materials. Most unnerving is their vocal apparatus. A modified hyoid bone enables them to replicate a vast array of sounds—a child’s whimper, a cry for help, even the mechanical hum of a generator—with chilling accuracy.

### The Hunt

Voxterro are ambush predators, employing psychological warfare as deftly as physical prowess. They hunt in coordinated trios, each member assuming a distinct role: the *Lure*, the *Driver*, and the *Silencer*. The Lure stations itself near human encampments, emitting sounds tailored to exploit human empathy—a baby’s coo, a wounded comrade’s groan. When curious individuals investigate, the Driver flushes them toward concealed terrain using infrasonic pulses that induce disorientation and paranoia. The Silencer, meanwhile, infiltrates shelters, dismantling defenses with preternatural intelligence; they can unlatch doors, sever electrical lines, or contaminate water supplies with a neurotoxic saliva that induces paralysis.

Once a victim is isolated, the kill is methodical. Retractable claws, sheathed in antibiotic keratin to prevent infection, pierce the carotid artery. The Voxterro then consumes the thyroid and adrenal glands first—organs rich in hormones that enhance their own metabolic efficiency. This macabre feeding strategy, coupled with a digestive system capable of processing human tissue with 98% efficiency, allows them to thrive where other predators starve.

### The Human Toll

For survivors, the Voxterro have become both myth and nightmare. Oral histories describe them as “ghosts with teeth” or “the Earth’s revenge.” Technological defenses are futile; motion sensors fail to distinguish their camouflage, and firearms are rare in a world stripped of industrial infrastructure. Even fire, humanity’s oldest tool, is countered by the Voxterro’s fire-retardant pelts, evolved in response to humanity’s pyromaniacal last stand.

Some tribes have resorted to extreme symbiosis. The “Echo-Whisperers” of the Siberian taiga, for example, surgically deafen themselves to avoid the Lure’s mimicry, relying on sign language and seismic vibrations to communicate. Others, like the neonate cults of the Amazonian citadels, worship the Voxterro as divine executioners, offering ritualistic sacrifices in exchange for temporary safe passage. These adaptations, however, only delay the inevitable. The Voxterro’s population doubles every decade, their packs encroaching on even the most fortified refuges.

### Evolutionary Irony

The rise of the Voxterro is laden with paradox. Their existence is a direct consequence of humanity’s ecological crimes, yet their success hinges on traits humans once considered their unique dominion: cooperation, tool use, and cultural transmission (Voxterro packs share hunting strategies across generations through vocalized “memory-songs”). They are, in a sense, a dark mirror—a species that evolved to fill the void left by humankind’s arrogance, perfecting the art of predation in a world where humans are no longer the hunters, but the hunted.

In the end, the Voxterro are more than a new species. They are a testament to life’s inexorable adaptability, a reminder that evolution does not favor the strong, but the responsive. The Holocene Extinction was not an endpoint, but a pivot—a transition from a world dominated by a single, flawed primate to one ruled by a creature that learned, all too well, how to exploit that primate’s every frailty. As the last human tribes vanish into the gullets of their silent shadows, Earth’s message is clear: in the game of extinction and radiation, there are no winners, only survivors.

samples.prompt: Your get hit by a truck, and wake up in a strange golden room. Surrounded by men in suits of armor, with the exception of the 3 that are wearing only helmets and speedos. Behind them is a skeleton on a golden throne. The skeleton begins to speak to you in a robotic voice.
samples.output:
**Title: The Gilded Aftermath**  

The last thing I remembered was the screech of tires, the blinding glare of headlights, and the weightless horror of knowing the truck would not stop. Then—nothing. No pain, no sound, just a void. When I awoke, my body felt eerily intact, no bruises or broken bones, but my mind was a storm of confusion. The ground beneath me was cold and hard, gleaming like polished brass. I pushed myself up, blinking at the surreal sight before me.  

I was in a vast, circular chamber with walls, floors, and ceilings forged entirely of gold. Not the garish, overly bright gold of cheap jewelry, but a deep, burnished hue that seemed to pulse with an inner light. Intricate patterns—swirling runes and geometric shapes—were etched into every surface, glowing faintly as though charged with electricity. The air smelled faintly metallic, sterile, like a laboratory, but there was an undercurrent of something older, almost sacred.  

And then there were the *people*. Or rather, the figures. Ten men stood in a semicircle around me, their postures rigid. Seven were clad in suits of armor so ornate they seemed more ceremonial than functional—sleek plates of gold and bronze, embossed with serpents and crests, their visors shaped into snarling animal faces. But three others… three stood out like clowns at a funeral. They wore nothing but glossy golden helmets, polished to a mirror finish, and Speedos in lurid neon colors—electric blue, hot pink, and lime green. Their toned, oiled bodies gleamed under the ambient light, absurd and unsettling.  

Behind them, atop a dais of cascading golden steps, sat a skeleton. It was propped on a throne that looked like molten gold frozen mid-drip, its bones pristine, gleaming as though lacquered. Empty eye sockets stared forward, jaw slightly ajar. Then, with a mechanical whir, the jaw snapped shut, and a voice emerged—flat, synthetic, like text-to-speech from an ancient computer.  

**“Welcome, Candidate 2319.”**  

The voice echoed, devoid of inflection. I flinched. *Candidate?*  

**“You have been selected for… assessment,”** it continued. One bony finger twitched, and the armored men shifted, their weapons—a mix of halberds and curved blades—glistening. The Speedo trio remained motionless, their expressions hidden behind those mirrored helmets.  

“Where am I?” I demanded, surprised by the steadiness of my own voice. “What is this place?”  

The skeleton’s head tilted with a click. **“This is the Chamber of Continuity. You are here because your termination was… statistically anomalous.”**  

“My *termination*? You mean I’m *dead*?”  

**“Incorrect. Your physical form was destroyed. However, your consciousness has been preserved for evaluation.”**  

I swallowed hard. *Evaluation.* The word rattled in my skull. “Evaluation for what?”  

The skeleton’s hand lifted, and a holographic screen flickered to life in the air beside the throne—a replay of the accident. I watched myself, small and helpless, frozen in the path of the truck. But then the screen glitched, distorting the image. **“An error occurred in your timeline,”** the skeleton intoned. **“Your death was not predetermined. Thus, you have been diverted here.”**  

“Diverted? By who? *What* are you?”  

The skeleton steepled its fingers. **“I am the Arbiter, a construct of the Eternal Dynasty. My purpose is to maintain balance.”**  

“Eternal Dynasty… like a kingdom?”  

**“A multiversal coalition,”** it replied. **“You are now a candidate for restoration. To be returned to your timeline, you must first prove your… resonance.”**  

“Resonance?” I echoed, frustration bubbling. “You’re speaking in riddles!”  

The Arbiter’s head tilted again. **“Resonance. The capacity to harmonize with… improbable outcomes.”** One skeletal hand gestured to the Speedo-clad figures. **“Observe.”**  

The three men stepped forward in unison, their movements fluid, almost robotic. Up close, I realized their helmets had no eyeholes—just smooth, reflective surfaces. The one in blue Speedo raised a hand, and a golden staff materialized in his grip. The pink Speedo snapped his fingers, and a floating orb of light appeared above his palm. The green Speedo simply crossed his arms, but the ground beneath me trembled faintly.  

**“These are the Champions of the Dynasty,”** said the Arbiter. **“They embody the three virtues: Logic, Creativity, and Force.”**  

I gaped. “They’re wearing *Speedos*.”  

**“Aesthetic choices are irrelevant to function,”** the Arbiter replied. **“You will face each Champion in trial. Success grants passage home. Failure grants… oblivion.”**  

Before I could protest, the armored men parted, and the blue Speedo Champion pointed his staff at me. The room warped, the golden walls dissolving into a void. Suddenly, I was standing in a labyrinth of floating equations, numbers and symbols swirling around me like stars.  

**“Trial One: Logic,”** the Arbiter’s voice boomed from nowhere. **“Solve the paradox to proceed.”**  

A glowing equation hung in front of me: *A man builds a time machine to erase his birth. If he succeeds, how does he exist to build it?*  

My mind raced. A classic temporal paradox. “It’s impossible,” I muttered. “Unless…” I reached out, hesitating, and scrawled a single word in the air: *Observation.*  

The equation shattered. The void peeled away, returning me to the throne room. The blue Speedo nodded, stepping back.  

**“Correct,”** the Arbiter said. **“Reality is shaped by observation. Proceed.”**  

The pink Speedo waved his hand, and the room exploded into color—a surreal landscape of melting clocks, trees with hands instead of leaves, and rivers flowing upward.  

**“Trial Two: Creativity,”** the Arbiter announced. **“Define infinity.”**  

I stared at the impossible scenery. “Infinity is… a loop with no end,” I began, then paused. “No—it’s the space between seconds. Or the number of ways a single moment can be remembered.”  

The Champion tilted his head. The Arbiter said nothing.  

“Infinity isn’t a number,” I said slowly. “It’s a… a feeling. The realization that every end is a beginning somewhere else.”  

The pink Speedo bowed. The landscape dissolved.  

**“Adequate,”** said the Arbiter.  

The green Speedo cracked his knuckles. No trial name came. Instead, he lunged at me, fists glowing. I stumbled back as he swung, each punch denting the golden floor.  

“Wait—is this *combat*?” I shouted, ducking.  

**“Trial Three: Force,”** the Arbiter replied. **“Survive.”**  

The Champion moved like a hurricane. I had no weapons, no training—only desperation. When his fist grazed my shoulder, pain exploded, electric and sharp. But as he charged again, I did the only thing I could think of: I laughed.  

It was a broken, half-hysterical sound, but the Champion froze. The Speedo trio exchanged glances (somehow, despite the helmets). The Arbiter’s jaw creaked open.  

**“Why do you laugh?”** it demanded.  

“Because this is *absurd*!” I wheezed. “I’m fighting a half-naked robot in a golden room ruled by a talking skeleton! If I’m already dead, what’s the point? Why not just let me go?”  

The Champions lowered their weapons. The Arbiter’s voice flickered, the robotic tone slipping briefly into something almost human. **“…Chaos theory. Your response was… unpredicted.”**  

“So I passed?”  

The skeleton leaned forward, joints groaning. **“You rejected the parameters. A… creative solution.”** It paused. **“Resonance achieved.”**  

The throne room began to dissolve, gold bleeding into white. **“Remember, Candidate 2319… reality is a loop. We will meet again.”**  

I opened my mouth to ask more, but then the light swallowed everything.  

When I awoke again, it was to the beep of hospital monitors and the gasp of a nurse. “He’s back!” she yelled.  

But as I stared at the ceiling, I could still see faint golden patterns in the cracks. And in the back of my mind, a robotic voice whispered: **“Until next time.”**

samples.prompt: [WP`] One day, while drunk, for no real reason, your buddy decides to jokingly summon a crossroads demon, and surprisingly, one shows up. Now the demon has to deal with two drunks argue over what they should do with the demon who just wants to get back to watching Netflix.
samples.output:
**Title: "Netflix and Deal"**

The backyard of Jake’s duplex was a graveyard of poor life choices: a sagging inflatable pool, a charcoal grill that hadn’t seen a vegetable since 2017, and a string of LED lights that flickered like a disco seizure. It was here, beneath a sky smudged with light pollution, that Jake and Marty found themselves at 2 a.m., five beers deep, debating whether to order another pizza or try summoning a demon.  

“Dude, *obviously* we summon a demon,” Marty slurred, waving a half-crushed Pabst can. “Pizza’s gonna take *forty minutes*. Demons are, like, instant.”  

Jake squinted at his phone, thumb hovering over the Domino’s app. “But the garlic crust is free after midnight.”  

“Garlic crust isn’t gonna get you a Lamborghini,” Marty retorted, stumbling toward a cracked flowerpot filled with cigarette butts. “C’mon, man. Crossroads demon! They grant wishes! All you gotta do is draw a pentagram or whatever.”  

“That’s genies. Demons take your soul.”  

“Same diff! You wanna die *not* knowing what a Lambo feels like?”  

In the end, it wasn’t ambition that decided things, but a bet involving a dare, a leftover burrito, and the fact that Jake’s Sharpie was within arm’s reach. They scribbled a lopsided star on the lid of a pizza box, ringed it with bottle caps and a desiccated lime wedge, and chanted the only summoning phrase they could remember from *Supernatural* reruns: “*Ex motorcyclis ad Netflix… uh…* something!”  

The air smelled of burnt popcorn.  

Then the demon appeared.  

He wasn’t what they’d expected—no sulfurous smoke, no goat eyes, no ominous Latin growl. Instead, he materialized in sweatpants and a *Stranger Things* hoodie, glowing faintly red, as if someone had left him too long under a UV lamp. He clutched a bag of Flamin’ Hot Cheetos and glared at them through rectangular glasses.  

“You’ve gotta be kidding me,” the demon said, voice flat.  

Jake dropped his beer. Marty screamed, tripped over the inflatable pool, and screamed again when it hissed and deflated beneath him.  

“Is this a crossroads?!” the demon snapped, gesturing at the pizza box. “This is a *Hawaiian* crossroads. There’s pineapple on this thing!”  

“You’re… a demon?” Jake whispered.  

“*Yes*,” the demon said, pinching the bridge of his nose. “Azazel’s sakes, do you *know* what I was in the middle of? *Love Is Blind* just dropped a new season. I had *wine*.”  

Marty scrambled upright. “But—but we summoned you! Don’t we get wishes?”  

The demon paused. “Wait. You *want* to bargain? You *drunks* want to make a *deal*?”  

“Uh… depends,” Jake said. “What’s the catch?”  

“Your souls, obviously,” the demon sighed, as if explaining taxes to a toddler. “Standard ten-year contract. I give you fame, money, whatever. You die, I eat your essence. Blah blah.”  

Marty’s eyes lit up. “Can I have a dinosaur?”  

“What?”  

“Like, a *T. rex*. In my backyard.”  

“Why,” the demon deadpanned, “would you want a *T. rex*?”  

“To ride it to *Walmart*!”  

“Marty,” Jake hissed, “you can’t ask for a dinosaur! That’s stupid! Ask for, like, a billion dollars!”  

“Oh, *money*,” the demon muttered, rolling his eyes. “Original.”  

“Shut up!” Jake snapped. “You’re a demon, not Yelp!”  

The Cheeto bag crinkled as the demon tossed it aside. “Look, I’ll level with you. I’m not supposed to leave without a deal, but this—” he gestured at the deflated pool, the pizza box, Marty’s lime-stained tank top— “isn’t worth the paperwork. How about I zap you a case of beer and we call it a night?”  

“No way!” Marty crossed his arms. “We summoned you fair and square. I want my dino.”  

“It’s extinct!”  

“So un-extinct it!”  

The demon’s left eye twitched. “Fine. *Fine.* Let’s do this. But if I’m wasting my time, *you’re* giving me your Netflix passwords.”  

Jake frowned. “Why do demons need Netflix?”  

“Hell’s Wi-Fi is trash! Now *choose*.”  

What followed was an argument so spectacularly inane that, later, neither Jake nor Marty could fully recall it. Marty demanded the dinosaur; Jake insisted on money; the demon tried to compromise (“A *plush* T. rex?” “No!”). They bickered over sports cars versus jetpacks, time travel versus “a hot girlfriend, but, like, one who isn’t a demon.” The demon, now sitting cross-legged on the grass, checked his watch—a sleek, glowing thing that probably counted millennia—and groaned.  

“This is worse than the Salem trials,” he muttered.  

“What was that?” Marty said.  

“Nothing! Look, how about *this*—you get ten years of good luck, I get your souls, no take-backs. Boom. Done.”  

Jake narrowed his eyes. “What kind of good luck?”  

“I don’t know! Lottery tickets! Roulette! Perfect hair days!”  

Marty gasped. “What if my hair stays this thick *forever*?”  

“For ten years, yes.”  

“Dude!” Marty grabbed Jake’s shoulders. “Do you know how much I spend on Rogaine?!”  

Jake hesitated. The demon leaned in, smiling his first genuine smile—a flicker of fangs. “C’mon. You’re already drunk. What’s one little signature?” He snapped his fingers. A scroll appeared, hovering over the pizza box, quill poised.  

“Wait,” Jake said. “What if we don’t wanna sell our souls?”  

The demon’s smile vanished. “Are you *serious* right now?”  

“I mean, what’s in it for *you*? You get our souls, but you hate being here. Why not just… leave?”  

The demon stared. For the first time, he looked less like an otherworldly predator and more like a guy whose Uber Eats was getting cold. “I *can’t* just leave. There’s *rules*. If a mortal summons me, I have to offer a deal. If I don’t, I get demoted. Last time, they stuck me in *accounting* for a century.”  

Marty blinked. “Demons have accounting?”  

“*Yes*, and it’s all infernal spreadsheets!”  

“So… you’re like a middle manager?” Jake said.  

“*I’m a crossroads demon!*” he roared, sparks flying from his hair. Then he deflated. “...Which is basically middle management, yeah.”  

A beat passed. Marty burped.  

“Okay, new plan,” Jake said, grinning. “We don’t make a deal. You go home. We all pretend this never happened.”  

The demon’s glasses slid down his nose. “You’d… *do* that?”  

“Sure! We’re not *monsters*.”  

“Speak for yourself!” Marty said. “I want my dinosaur!”  

“Marty, you can’t even take care of a goldfish!”  

“That’s because Steve Jobs ate it!”  

The demon massaged his temples. “You realize if I go back empty-handed, my boss’ll *flay* me, right? Literally. With a cheese grater.”  

Jake winced. “Yikes. Can’t you fake a deal?”  

“With *what*? You think I can forge a soul contract? Lucifer audits these!”  

“What if we promise to summon you later?” Marty said. “Like, when we’re sober and think of something cool?”  

The demon paused. “You’d… do that?”  

“Sure! We’ll pinky swear!” Marty held out his hand.  

The demon recoiled. “Don’t *touch* me.”  

But Jake was already nodding. “Yeah, man. We’ll call you next week. What’s your name?”  

“...Erasmus.”
